statement:
#### Introduction.

It is frequent to make use of Cauchy integral formula to represent
analytically some functions that are useful in mathematical physics
applications. However, it must be noted that such representation is not
unique, so that the same function can be represented by different
integrals of Cauchy’s type. An important case has to do with the
equality of the two Cauchy integrals $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_C\frac{\psi_1(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta=
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_C\frac{\psi_2(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta\end{aligned}$$
for all values of $z$ in the interior of $C$. In general no conclusion
can be drawn concerning the equality of the density functions
$\psi_1(\zeta)$ and $\psi_2(\zeta)$. We shall see, however, that if some
additional restriction are imposed on the density functions and on the
contour $C$, then the equality will occur. That is the matter of
[*Harnack theorem*]{}. In considering the applications of the theory of
functions of a complex variable to problems in continuum mechanics, for
instance, we shall most frequently deal with the region bounded by the
unit circle, i.e. the compact disc $|z|\leq 1$ that we shall draw in the
$z$-plane, its boundary will be denoted by $\gamma$ and the points of
$\gamma$ by $\zeta=e^{i\theta}$. All density functions of the argument
$\theta$ will be assumed to be $2\pi$-periodic.

[[^1]]{}Let $f(\theta)$ and $g(\theta)$ be continuous real functions of
the argument $\theta$ defined on the boundary $\gamma$; if
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{f(\theta)d\zeta}{\zeta-z}=
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{g(\theta)d\zeta}{\zeta-z}\end{aligned}$$
then $$\begin{aligned}
f(\theta)\equiv g(\theta) \qquad if \qquad |z|<1\end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}
f(\theta)=g(\theta)+const. \qquad if \qquad |z|>1.\end{aligned}$$

1.  $|z|<1$. From equality (1) we obtain $$\begin{aligned}
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{f(\theta)-g(\theta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta\equiv
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{h(\theta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta\equiv 0,\end{aligned}$$
    where $h(\theta)\equiv f(\theta)-g(\theta)$. We shall prove that
    $h(\theta)\equiv 0$. Since $|z|<1$ we can write, $$\begin{aligned}
    \frac{1}{\zeta-z}=\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{z^n}{\zeta^{n+1}}\:,\end{aligned}$$
    then $$\begin{aligned}
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{h(\theta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta=
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}
    \oint_\gamma\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{h(\theta)}{\zeta^{n+1}}z^n d\zeta=
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}\sum_{n=0}^\infty(a_n-ib_n)z^n,\end{aligned}$$ the
    complex form of Fourier series [[^2]]{}where the coefficients are
    given by (we are using the Euler’s formula) $$\begin{aligned}
    a_n-ib_n=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{h(\theta)}{\zeta^{n+1}}d\zeta
    =\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}\!\!h(\theta)e^{-in\theta}d\theta.\end{aligned}$$
    But (2) vanishes for all values of $z$, therefore
    $a_n=b_n=0,\, n\in\mathbb{N}$ and a reference to Fourier complex
    expansion $$\begin{aligned}
    h(\theta)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty c_ne^{in\theta}, \qquad 
    c_n=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}h(t)e^{-int}dt, \quad n\in\mathbb{Z},\end{aligned}$$
    shows that all Fourier coefficients of the function $h(\theta)$
    vanish, and hence $h(\theta)\equiv 0$.

2.  $|z|>1$. By analytic continuation, we have $$\begin{aligned}
    \frac{1}{\zeta-z}=\sum_{n=0}^\infty -\frac{\zeta^n}{z^{n+1}}\:,\end{aligned}$$
    so that $$\begin{aligned}
    \frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{h(\theta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta=
    -\frac{1}{2\pi i}
    \oint_\gamma\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\zeta^{n-1}h(\theta)}{z^n}d\zeta=
    -\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{a_n+ib_n}{z^n}\:,\end{aligned}$$ where
    $$\begin{aligned}
    a_n+ib_n=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\zeta^{n-1}h(\theta)d\zeta=
    \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}\!\!h(\theta)e^{in\theta}d\theta, \quad 
    n\in\mathbb{N}\backslash\{0\}.\end{aligned}$$ Since (3) vanishes for
    all values of $|z|>1$, $a_n=b_n=0,\, n\in\mathbb{N}\backslash\{0\}$.
    Thus, all Fourier coefficients of $h(\theta)$, with the possible
    exception of $a_0$, vanish and hence $$\begin{aligned}
    g(\theta)=f(\theta)+const.\end{aligned}$$

Moreover, from this theorem if $|z|>1$ and in addition to (1) we have
the equality $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{f(\theta)}{\zeta}d\zeta=
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{g(\theta)}{\zeta}d\zeta,\end{aligned}$$
then $f(\theta)=g(\theta)$.

Given the continuous real functions $f_1,f_2,g_1,g_2$ and the following
simultaneous equalities for all values of $z$. $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{f_1+if_2}{\zeta-z}d\zeta=
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{g_1+ig_2}{\zeta-z}d\zeta,\end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{f_1-if_2}{\zeta-z}d\zeta=
\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_\gamma\frac{g_1-ig_2}{\zeta-z}d\zeta,\end{aligned}$$
then $$\begin{aligned}
g_1=f_1, \qquad g_2=f_2, \qquad if \quad |z|<1,\end{aligned}$$ and
$$\begin{aligned}
g_1=f_1+const., \qquad g_2=f_2+const., \qquad if \quad |z|>1.\end{aligned}$$
By adding and substracting those equalities, this corollary follows from
Harnack theorem.

[99]{} N. I. Muskhelishvili’s, [*Singular Integral Equations,*]{} p.64,
1953. E.C. Titchmarsh, [*The Theory of Functions,*]{} Oxford University
Press, New York, 2d ed., pp. 64-101, 399-428. W.F. Osgood, [*Lehrbuch
der Funktionentheorie*]{}, Teubner Verlagsgesellschaft, Leipzig, vol. 1.
Ã‰. Goursat, [*Course d’analyse,*]{} Gauthiers-Villars & Cie, Paris,
vol. 2. E. Picard, [*Leçons sur quelques types simples d’Ã©quations aux
dÃ©rivÃ©es partielles,*]{} Gauthiers-Villars & Cie, Paris.

[^1]: A less restrictive form of Harnack theorem is discussed in
    [@cite:Musk].

[^2]: The restrictions imposed upon the expanded function are known as
    the Dirichlet conditions, but it is sufficient to demand that it be
    a function of bounded variation.
